title: 103_hr3434
content: The "Smoke-Free Environment Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new title on smoke-free environments, establishing a smoke-free environment policy. The "Smoke-Free Environment Act of 1993" requires public facilities to adopt a smoke-free environment policy to protect individuals from the health risks of environmental tobacco smoke. The policy must prohibit smoking and tobacco combustion on facility property and display clear no-smoking notices. The policy allows for specially designated smoking areas within a public facility if they meet ventilation requirements and do not require nonsmoking individuals to enter. SEC. 2702. CITIZEN ACTIONS. An action to enforce the requirements of this title can be brought by an aggrieved person, State or local government agency, or the Administrator in any United States district court. The court can issue an injunction or impose a civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day of violation. Prior notice of at least 60 days must be given to the alleged violator before commencing an action. The court may award costs of litigation, including attorney fees, to a prevailing plaintiff in actions brought under this section. The court also has the discretion to use civil penalties for projects that align with the policies of this title, after consulting with the Administrator. SEC. 2703 states that this title does not override other laws protecting from environmental tobacco smoke. SEC. 2704 authorizes the Administrator to create necessary regulations. SEC. 2705 specifies the effective date of the requirements, one year after enactment. SEC. 2706 provides definitions. SEC. 2706 defines key terms for this title, including 'Administrator,' 'public facility,' and 'responsible entity.'
